epigraphs.text: The forms of liberty may remain long after the spirit has vanished.
When law is bent to purpose, it remembers the hand that bent it more than the people it was meant to serve.
The most effective censorship is not the burning of books, but the quiet removal of pages no one notices are gone.

long_synopsis: Week 29 of Trump’s second term was defined less by a single rupture than by the knitting together of law, force, money, and narrative into a tighter web of control. The Democracy Clock stayed at 8:06 p.m., yet core traits of authoritarian governance deepened: law as weapon, executive power without real oversight, and stratified citizenship. In Texas and Indiana, mid‑decade gerrymanders backed by threats of arrest, FBI assistance, and retaliatory investigations turned representation into an executive project. At the federal level, the Justice Department and FBI were purged and repurposed, with grand juries and subpoenas aimed at Obama‑era officials, Jack Smith, and New York Attorney General Letitia James. Economic and immigration policy fused public authority with private gain and carceral expansion, from Medicare favors for donors to vast new ICE contracts and detention complexes. Universities were disciplined through funding threats and data mandates, while official statistics, archives, and human‑rights reports were attacked, curated, or quietly altered. The moral floor continued to collapse inside an already darkened hour.
